alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for income tax paid on directors' behalf
overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers paying income tax on a directors' behalf
title: Expenses and benefits: income tax paid on directors' behalf

table.body:
As an employer paying income tax on behalf of company directors, you have certain National Insurance and reporting obligations.

##What’s included

If you pay a company director without deducting tax under PAYE, and HMRC then recovers the unpaid tax from you, this counts as a benefit.

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]:Pay As You Earn
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You might not have to report or pay anything to HMRC if the director doesn't have a 'material interest' in your company, and either of the following applies:

* they're a full-time working director
* your company is a charity or not-for-profit organisation

In broad terms, a director has a material interest in a company if they (alone or together with associates) own or can control more than 5% of its ordinary share capital. This is explained in more detail in the [technical guidance](/expenses-and-benefits-income-tax-paid-on-directors-behalf/technical-guidance "technical guidance").

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: What's exempt

table.body:
If the income tax you pay on a director's behalf isn't [exempt](/expenses-and-benefits-income-tax-paid-on-directors-behalf/whats-exempt "exempt"), you’ll need to:

* report on form P11D, section M
* add the [value of the benefit](/expenses-and-benefits-income-tax-paid-on-directors-behalf/work-out-the-value "value of the benefit") to the director’s earnings when deducting and paying Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through your payroll

*[PAYE]:Pay As You Earn
table.title: What to report and pay

table.body:
Use the amount of tax recovered from you by HMRC, minus any amount paid back to you ('made good') by the director.

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
